bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. KILDEE:H.R. 2928.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Section 8: The Congress shall have Power . . . To regulateCommerce with foreign Nations, and among the several States,and with the Indian Tribes.[Page H6182]

item.title: A bill to provide relief to the Pottawatomi Nation in Canada for settlement of certain claims against the United States.

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. (text of measure as introduced: CR S174)

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee Indian and Alaska Native Affairs.
Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

summary.text:
Directs the Secretary of the Treasury to pay a specified sum to the Pottawatomi Nation in Canada in settlement and full satisfaction of certain claims.

Excludes such payment from the provisions of the Indian Tribal Judgment Funds Use or Distribution Act.

bill.title: To provide relief to the Pottawatomi Nation in Canada for settlement of certain claims against the United States.

item.title: To provide relief to the Pottawatomi Nation in Canada for settlement of certain claims against the United States.
To provide relief to the Pottawatomi Nation in Canada for settlement of certain claims against the United States.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee Indian and Alaska Native Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
